Education

Mission

BeagleBoard.org cares about empowering students of all ages to understand and build upon the contemporary skills of programming and electronics. These computer-related skills are fundamental to the technologies that drive an ever-growing presence in all of our lives.

Vision

We characterize our vision as "Kindergarten to Kickstarter" where building with electronics can be drag-and-drop easy and no barriers exist to taking your creations anywhere. Our BeagleBone Black ships pre-programmed with a Linux distribution configured to serve up a web page over USB or Ethernet that walks you through basic hardware interactions using JavaScript in your browser. The included browser-based Cloud9 IDE served up from the board enables you to quickly take the next steps to creating your own programs and interacting directly with the Linux command-line, without needing to download, install or use any additonal tools.

Approach

We seek to provide the lowest total out of pocket cost to build your lab. While BeagleBone Black does support connecting a keyboard, monitor and mouse to act as a desktop computer, we primarily educate people to use it as a "server" where you remotely access it from your own desktop, laptop or Chromebook. This configuration more closely matches how you would typically work with electronics as an appliance, rather than an application. When equiping a school, inexpensive laptops that include keyboard and monitor tend to be more cost-effective than buying separate monitors and keyboards, though we do happily support such a configuration if you already have purchased these items. It is not necessary to buy additional power supplies, SD cards or programmers as the USB on BeagleBone Black provides a mechanism to power the board as well as re-program the pre-programmed on-board flash.

Support

All BeagleBoard.org boards are supported by a community of tens of thousands of developers at all experience levels and backgrounds through live chat, a mailing list and web-based forum. Users are encouraged to first seek answers through web-based searches, then produce well-formed queries to the community describing what they hope to accomplish, what they tried, what they saw and why their expectations have not yet been met. Users typically get responses within just a few minutes or hours, but are welcome to escalate to Jason Kridner personally if you have no useful response within 24 hours.

Solutions

Sign up for updates

Provide your e-mail address on the sign-up page to be notified of new BeagleBoard.org electronics education solutions.

  • Sign up page

Engage the Texas Instruments University Program

Texas Instruments has a resource page on BeagleBone Black for Universities and you can contact Cathy Wicks for information on setting up university labs.

BeagleBone Textbooks

For a complete list of books on BeagleBone, see http://beagleboard.org/books.

Bad to the Bone

Perfect for high-school seniors or freshman univerisity level text, consider using "Bad to the Bone"

BeagleBone Cookbook

A lighter treatment suitable for a bit broader audience without the backgrounders on programming and electronics, consider "BeagleBone Cookbook"

Exploring BeagleBone and Embedded Linux Primer

To take things to the next level of detail, consider "Exploring BeagleBone" which can be considered the missing software manual and utilize "Embedded Linux Primer" as a companion textbook to provide a strong base on embedded Linux suitable for working with any hardware that will run Linux.

BeagleBone Educator

The BeagleBone Educator is a platform under development derived from BeagleBone Black. We are currently demonstrating and developing curriculum based on a cape (daughterboard) prototype called "the BeagleBone Education Blanket". Initial curriculum is expected tobe available in Fall 2016. Development of a cost-optimized all-in-one solution is on-going.

  • BeagleBone Educator flyer

For more information, be sure to select "Education" in your interests on the mailing list sign-up preferences.
